title: Poor crocs and agressive guides
text: Not much to see. Just poor crocs, have no idea how they poison them to keep that calm. Entrance is 100 D, which is ok. But then the so called "guides" will force you to take them for the tips that are 300-400 D (absolutely for nothing). And if you refuse, they gets very agressive and start shouting, including racist abuse. So don"t make them happy, skip this place.

title: Doing the place up nicely
text: Went to see the crocodiles today with my family, the  museum has had work done to it to make it much better for the public and also the crocodile place was having work done to it too. The tour guy was amazing who walked us round and supported us to touch the crocs. What an amazing experience this was thanks so much to everyone who was part of this.

title: Amazing
text:
This place is good value for money, as a small museum is also on site.
I would advise you have a taxi or take an official tour to get there as it is located in the middle of a busy local area and may be difficult to find as there is not much in the way of signage!

title: Heilige krokodillenvijver
text: In Katchikally bevindt zich al meer dan 500 jaar de Crocodile Pool. Het is een bedevaartsoord, veel mensen geloven dat de dieren heilig zijn en dat deze je kunnen helpen bij je vruchtbaarheid. Veel vrouwen wassen zich met het krokodillenwater. De beesten zijn overigens getemd, sommigen zijn zelfs aaibaar.

title: Spannend
text: Je loopt samen met de gids dwars door de krokodillen, ze krijgen elke dag voer, zodat ze niet hongerig zijn. Best wel een aparte ervaring

title: Leuk
text: Voor een heel klein bedrag krijg je een behoorlijke uitleg en mag je de krokodillen aaien. Als je ze gevoederd wil zien worden ga je best rond 16 u.

title: Wild Crocodiles you can touch
text:
The town of Bakau, just 12 km from Banjul, the capital of The Gambia, hosts an interesting site.  A pool with crocodiles, which inexplicably allow themselves to be touched and petted.  The pool is named Kachikally (also Katchically or Katchikali) and belongs to the Bojang family which has been administering it for 500ish years.

The site is promoted to be a sacred pool in which barren women can bath to wash away whatever has been holding them back from conceiving.  After performing the sacred ritual bathing, she is told to remain faithful to her husband and not to shake hands with other men for a year.  Faithfully adherence should bring her a child.  Required elements of the ritual includes bringing ‚Äúa humble petition‚Äù of ‚ÄúKola-nuts and other small offers‚Äù to the Bojang family.

Entering, I was met by a guide who collected my entrance fee and led me about a hundred yards to the pool (after I suggested that I would visit the museum at the entrance at the end of my visit).  The pool and its surrounds are a kind of oasis in the middle of the town.  The approximately 9 acre site is surrounded by trees and swamp-like growth and you quickly forget that you are in the middle of a populous town.  Right in front of the pool lie the main attractions, 2 meter long crocodiles sunning themselves with their mouths wide open (which is their way of keeping cool).  I was the only visitor at the time, but it was startling to see several guides seated just 8-10 feet from these reptiles which strike such fear in southern US States and which generate headlines when their encounters go horribly bad for locals (and often their pets) caught by surprise. 

I took a step closer, and then another one.  Then there I was, bending over and petting a live crocodile, smiling at the camera as my guide took my picture.

As I said, I can‚Äôt explain why I became complacent.  It just seemed perfectly natural to wander around the crocodiles, touching them, asking questions, and staring into their gapping, tooth filled mouths.  Their semi-catatonic state made me think that perhaps they were sleeping (though their eyes were open and eerily followed you as you moved around).  I asked my guide about this, and he smiled again (in fact, I think he never quit smiling).  He asked me to get my video camera ready.  He said that they were always alert, and ready to pounce on food to which they would be alerted based on the vibration it would make when it hit the ground.  Sure enough, he tossed a stick, and as you can see in the video in my blog, they jumped when it hit the ground, and only stopped when its smell didn‚Äôt register as food.

I have more information about Kachikally in my blog, including a list of reasons you may want to visit and a video of how active the crocodiles are.  The link is in my profile.

title: Lifted the crocodile's legs
text: Health and Safety in Europe wouldn't let you do half the things you can do here. Pose for a photo cuddling a crocodile, lift up its legs & tail - amazing.

title: Crocs
text: I pop for a visit to see the crocodiles each time  in the area ... where else could you do this ?! Defiantly worth a visit , maybe not small children üòï

title: Crocodile pool
text: Place, where you can see crocodiles very close. You are in the same area with the crocodiles. It is little bit scary to be in same area with crocodiles. They move very fast but Charlie is one of the croc,  which you can touch and be with him in same picture. You can touch him behind and one of the worker is very close. They give lots of fish for crocs and that's why they are full and satisfied.

title: Tr√®s bonne exp√©rience
text: Tr√®s bonne exp√©rience. Le parc n'est pas tr√®s grand mais est bien tenu. Il est possible d'approcher de pr√®s les crocodiles, toujours sous le contr√¥le des √©co gardes. Il y a √©galement un mus√©e tr√®s int√©ressant sur plusieurs √©l√©ments de l'histoire de la Gambie. Il ne s'agit pas de la principale attraction mais si visite vaut le d√©tour.

title: great place to stroke a croc
text: I am known for having accidents so my partner was a little apprehensive about going here and allowing me to stroke a croc....what was he worrying about? The park is not that big so easy to walk around and there are a few crocs in the main lake you go to < they get one to come out and allow you up close to stroke it>  definitely an experience

title: Croc park
text: My son and I were apprehensive despite being told that the crocodiles were tame owing to the fact that they are well fed. Nevertheless, the staff were reassuring and lovely. It was a great experience which my son and I thoroughly enjoyed.

title: Extraordinary place to see crocs
text: I brought 2 groups here and they were both really excited to see the crocs in and around the pool. The price has been increased dramatically and the managers are in danger of pricing tourists out of here. The museum is interesting but dated in presentation and rather dusty. Visitors who haven't seen crocs before are invariably impressed with the pool. A must see if you visit Gambia.

title: Amazing to see them up close
text:
Off the beaten track and through a very poor area in Bakou, you get to see a more real side of Gambia on your journey there.

There are dozens of crocs here, most of them down in the pond which is fenced off so you can look down without fear of them approaching or you falling in... There are also 1 or 2 up at the top where the guides allow you to go to close to them and take pictures as well as touch them. Crocs are fed a lot of food on the morning so they are not interested in attacking (or even moving), hence the guides assuring you of your safety (They aren't drugged despite the bad reviews)

Definitely worth a visit with a tourist taxi rather than a big group, there were less than 10 people there when we visited, well worth spending an hour or so there

title: Possibly most unnerving experience ever....
text:
But really glad we did this. 

Go with a local guide. There‚Äôs a nice museum at the entrance and a local guide will give you a real flavour of history here and talk about their own tribal histories and customs. 

The walk to the pool itself is interesting - very old tree as well as flora and fauna. 

You suddenly come upon the crocodiles and the first thought is ‚Äúoh that‚Äôs a realistic model‚Äù and then you realise the croc next to your foot is alive....

The crocodile keepers are excellent and touching a live croc was something I won‚Äôt forget. Which is good because I‚Äôm not doing it again either!

This was a real highlight. The animals are well cared for and are not drugged or mistreated. Definitely something to do whilst visiting locally.

title: dazed crocs
text: this is just a small park with crocodiles that look like they are drugged. they don't even hardly move and you can touch them.

title: Interesting and a little scary
text:
Before you enter to the crocodiles zone, you can visit a good museum showing a bit of Gambia's history, and an exhibition of musical instruments and traditional artifacts, it already starts good.
When you leave the museum, you will be located on the surroundings of a natural pool full of crocodiles, some of them resting around, or directly on your path! the guides know them all (at least this is how it looks) and they tell you which ones are dangerous and which are not, even those that you can touch and how to do it.
Maybe they shouldn't be selling souvenirs with crocodiles teeth, it's the only drawback for this attraction, however, I don't think that they kill them for that.

title: Museum and crocodile park
text:
Great little museum, lots of local information, ceremonial masks,instruments.. Was kind if disappointing so short but, worth it.. 
Crocodile park definitely needs investing but, if you can block that thought, its a nice little park.. Guide had lots of information not just about crocs, also fauna and wildlife..able to get close and take pictures guide very patient!!
Nice afternoon out..

title: Leuke en spannend uitje
text: Deze tour hebben wij gedaan, en is een echte aanrader voor avonturiers. Je ziet hoe de krokodillen leven, en hoe ze gevoerd worden. Je kunt ze aanraken/aaien. Er loopt er ook eentje (wellicht wel meer) rond die een poot mist doordat en ander deze heeft afgebeten in een gevecht.Onze kids en wijzelf vonden dit een hele leuke avontuurlijke excursie. Echt een aanrader!!

title: Crocs & A Lesson on The Gambia
text:
Yes you get to see crocodiles. Lots of them. You get to touch a few of them as well. Quite an experience.

What I feel should be mentioned is the little tour of the history of The Gambia as well as the people that you walk through efore getting to the crocs. Its well worth it to get someone knowledgable to take you through the little museum they have there.

No doubt the crocs are the main attraction but why not get a history lesson as well?

I think we paid D100 as an entrance fee. You'd be mad to pass up on this!

title: Great experience and well worth a visit.
text:
Small park area with a central pool containing circa 100 crocodiles. The guides claim they only eat fish and don't touch meat but he wasn't prepared to take the ¬£100 on offer to prove it by swimming across.
The opportunity to get up close and actually touch a crocodile. They do seem very tame but no doubt can 'turn' at any time so be careful. 
There's supposed to be a large albino croc called Charlie present but we didn't get to see him as he only appears at feeding time they say.
Lots of little crocs around out of the pool just basking in the sun. Don't walk off the beaten track though as you could easily stumble upon a nest of eggs with the mother watching over them. There's also a few snakes around so perhaps put on some long trousers for protection.
Small entry fee of 100 Gambian Dalasi (around ¬£1.50)
Nice little museum at the entrance charting some of the history of the area and the influence of the British under colonial rule.

title: Museum en heel veel krokodillen
text: De tweede keer dat wij hier kwamen. Het museum geeft veel informatie over de geschiedenis en cultuur van Gambia. In en om de krokodillenpoel zijn meer dan 100 krokodillen te vinden. Het blijven prachtige beesten, maar het zijn er wel heel erg veel die in deze "opvang" leven.

title: Fun
text:
The little museum at the entrance is very interesting and it was great to see all the crocodiles at the pool.  

It was recommended we visit late afternoon, glad we took that advice as we got to see so many of them!!

title: Amazing
text: wow wow wow loved this . Can‚Äôt believe we touched a croc. Amazing and a experience and memory that will last a lifetime

title: Second visit same awesome experience
text: So this was my second visit to the crocodile pool, this time i went with my 8 year old daughter, 6 year old nephew, sister and 2 year old niece. It was a 100 dalasi fee for entry for adults while the kids went in free. We started off with the tour of the mini museum then proceeded to the pool where the crocodiles are. You are allowed to touch the crocodiles and definitely pictures are allowed this is with the assistance of a tour guide. You can make voluntary donations that goes towards the feeding of the crocodiles, they are fed only fish. I will say it was yet again a beautiful experience.

title: Teveel krokodillen op een veel te kleine ruimte!
text: Katchikally Crocodile Pool was een tegenvaller. Meer dan 100 krokodillen zitten samen in een veel te kleine poel. De dieren op het droge vormen een soort van circusattractie: poseren met de toeristen. Sommige kroko's zaten zelfs in de halfopen en stinkende riolen. Absolutely not done voor zij die van dieren houden.

title: 'Holy Crocs'
text:
We, as a couple, visited the fairly basic crocodile pool while staying at The Kairaba Hotel. One hour should easily do. We had mixed feelings, we had the feeling that the animals were sedated and moreover got a 'Lacoste' touch - say, treating wild and normally voracious animals as pets. 
Optional donations are asked for and I wish to think that at a major part is for croc food. The surroundings give a chance to see how the locals live their lifes. Tip: take a taxi driver 'green' to organise the tour for you.

title: Great opportunity to pet a croc!
text: This croc pool is an excellent place for you to experience what it feels like to pet a crocodile! The place offers a nice visit and the guides there are really good. It is said that more than 100 crocs live in the pool, which is quite amazing since the pool isn't that big (but 5 meters deep and has underground cave system). There is also a local museum inside the park area.

title: Excursie
text:
Geweldig om dit mee te maken, ga zelf on tour met de mannen van TOC
Lokale reis leiders die dit prima doen!
Een gunning factor voor deze mensen

title: quite simply mad
text:
10-15 crocs 3 feet away and NO fences        MAD . 
The walk down to the pool is a must , check out the shops selling hand crafted wooden animals , and cloths

title: Katchikally Crocodile Pool ,a must see in the Gambia
text: Spent a hour or so at the Croc pool today as we looked around the Gambia, well worth a visit to see such prehistoric creatures so close up ,certainly a first for me and the wife stroking a crocodile, interesting little museum attached to the pool so made for a interesting visit ,with a cost of D200 well worth a look.

title: many crocodiles, none doing very much
text: I walked over to the Katchikally Crocodile Pool, in Bakau, which is in the middle of the town and not easy to find. There is first a pleasant museum with some masks and information about Gambia in the war. The pool itself is small and has many crocodiles, none doing very much. I stroked one on the back and it didn't seem to mind.

title: N√§ra m√∂te med krokodiler
text: Denna park √§r ganska enkel men det √§r en h√§ftig upplevelse att vara s√• n√§ra krokodiler och till och med f√• klappa dem, om du v√•gar! Mycket olikt andra parker kan krokodilerna h√§r r√∂ra sig mer eller mindre fritt. Jag har varit h√§r tv√• g√•nger. Ena g√•ngen promenerade vi fr√•n v√•rt hotell Sunbeach och √§ven promenaden genom ett enkelt bostadsomr√•de var en uppskattad del av utflykten.

title: Worth a visit!
text: I have been to Katchikally numerous times over the years and it is always worth going back to! What a novel thing to say you‚Äôve done on holiday, to shake a crocodile‚Äôs hand! Cheap and an interesting place to visit.

title: Curiosa visita.
text:
Cuando mi gu√≠a me comento que visitar√≠amos un museo con cocodrilos no pens√© que esto animales estar√≠an caminando por el recinto y al alcance de la mano (o tu al alcance de ellos ).
El museo refleja la historia, costumbres y tradiciones Gambianas a lo largo de la historia con fotograf√≠as y distintos art√≠culos expuestos, destacando los instrumentos musicales entre ellos una kora, grandes tambores ceremoniales y un xil√≥fono de madera de un metro y medio de largo.
Se pueden observar mascaras y vestimentas tradicionales.
Pero lo realmente espectacular es ver a los cocodrilos que se encuentran tanto en el estanque como en sus orillas.
La visita se realiza acompa√±ados por un gu√≠a que te indicara que cocodrilo puedes tocar, yo tras tocarlo y ver su inmovilidad en un primer momento pens√© que estaba disecado y cuando lo comente el gu√≠a hizo que se moviera y fue realmente impresionante ver al cocodrilo con las mand√≠bulas abiertas tan pr√≥ximo a mi.
Me explicaron que son cocodrilos del Nilo y que pueden llegar a medir hasta cuatro metros.

title: Eigenlijk heel triest
text:
Het is een attractie die je gezien moet hebben maar eigenlijk is t heel triest. Er liggen heel veel krokodillen in een klein goor watertje en op de paden. 
Het kost ook niet veel, 100 dalasi (‚Ç¨1,70) en na Afloop wordt er om een gift gevraagd om ze te ‚Äúvoeren en te verzorgen‚Äù.
Het ‚Äúmooiste‚Äù is eigenlijk het ritje er naar toe. Wij waren op de fiets en dan ga je echt door een soort sloppenwijk met een open riool.  
Goed alternatief is de kleine natuurlijke pool bij cape point, calypso beach bar. Daar liggen ze ook, maar dan op een betere plek.

title: One to make sure you visit!
text:
A really good place to visit in The Gambia. 

A lot of history and cultural significance to the area, a really interesting little museum. 

Highlight obviously the pool and touching the crocodiles! 

As always, expect to be asked for ‚Äòa tip‚Äô on top!

title: worth visiting
text: Very cheap entrance fee, little museum is good and to be literally stepping over crocodiles and being so close to them is great experience !!!

title: fasanating
text: fabulous place with a small museum showing the history of the gambia and the crocodiles are amazing to see and touch.

title: Great place for children of all ages.....
text: Allegedly, this sacred pool was established in 1860's or earlier - it is small and a bit grubby but you can get really close to the crocodiles. The small museum and huge trees - you can stand in one - make the whole visit great fun.

title: Leuke trip
text: Met Falutours deze trip gemaakt. Individuele begeleiding met gids die veel weet. Bij de crocodile pool de krokodillen geaaid. Gids legt alles uit over de krokodillen en ook hoe het is ontstaan

title: Quite a small pool with a large number of crocodiles
text: Called at Katchikally after a visit to Calypso Bar at Cape Point. It is a small pool with a large number of crocodiles in a fairly small area. 200d to enter the site, where there are a number of huts displaying Gambian history before visiting the pool. On reaching the pool a guide approached us and showed us around the pool. The crocodiles are well fed and very docile to the extent that they can be touched

title: Crocos wild!! :)
text: We went here with our local guide sonko (sonko1984@yahoo.com) who arranged everything. This place is cheap to go and close. Atmosphere was good, lots of crocos. And first time i had a chance to touch crocodile!! you can donate some money to this place if you want. i Recommend!

title: Wow!
text:
An amazing experience and a must-do...to touch a crocodile is a truly fantastic thing and they are not 'crunchy'!!!
Look out for the gigantic 'elephant tree'...it's something else

title: Heel leuk
text:
Erg leuk om een keer te doen. Krokodillen aaien doe je niet elke dag :)
Aardige gidsen lopen er rond

title: Not for the scared
text: Having held a baby croc in Zimbabwe, it was good to touch a full size one and have the photo to prove it, which I failed to do in Zim.

title: Nice
text:
We were taken here by our OTG tourist guide. There is a little museum on site followed by Croc pool. Yes, crocs are everywhere and there is also another guide who will speak to you a bit more about this attractions and will take you around the pond and let you touch some of the crocodiles. 

It's pretty cheap to visit, so do make sure you find a time to come here during your holiday.

title: Interesante visita a Kachikali
text: Esta es la tercera vez que estoy en este pa√≠s, me encanta Gambia, su gente y todo lo que hay que ver en el. La laguna de Kachikali, un lugar sagrado, est√° muy bien para visitarla, estar al lado de cocodrilos, poder acariciarlos y darles de comer pescado es muy interesante, dar una vuelta y hacer unas cuantas fotos merece la pena, a la entrada hay un mini museo con trajes y fotos que nos introduce un poco a la vida pasada de esta gente, yo particularmente lo recomiendo

title: Kort maar krachtig
text: Wel eens de moeite om te doen, of je nu wil of niet, je zal een krokodil aanraken ,wel eens leuk om aan voelen . Langer dan1 uur ben je er niet binnen.

title: Amazing
text:
It‚Äôs only a small place but well worth the visit, the crocodiles were so calm!

The guide was very knowledgeable and you were able to able touch the crocodiles which was pretty amazing.

For the price you pay you wouldn‚Äôt get this experience in England!

title: There be crocodiles
text: As with most things in Gambia this attraction is very run down and could do with some cash input, perhaps a bit on the admission fee would help towards that. However the guides were knowledgeable. They even managed to coax the 6 teenagers in our group to touch a crocodile. There is also a small museum on site which gives a bit of an insight into the counties heritage. Overall it is worth a visit

title: Krokodillen gezien
text: Lopend met een lokale gids uit een kiosk tegenover ons hotel (Sun Beach) naar de krokodillenpoel gelopen. Onderweg ernaar toe loop je door een straatarme wijk met open riolering en overal vuilnis. Aangekomen bij het park, ga je eerst naar het museum. Was wel interessant, over de geschiedenis van het park en Gambia als republiek. Er hangen ook veel handgemaakte muziekinstumenten. Lopend in het park kom je bij de krokodillenpoel. Er leven heel veel krokodillen en je kunt er ook een aanraken. De gids heeft veel verteld over het park, het schijnt dat vrouwen die graag een kind willen hebben, zich daar op een speciale plek kunnen wassen met water uit de poel. Er loopt iemand rond of je een bijdrage wil geven voor de vis die ze elke dag moeten kopen. Zolang ze vol zitten, eten ze uiteraard geen toeristen... terug door de wijk hele hordes kinderen achter ons aan die snoep willen en mensen die je schriften willen verkopen voor de kinderen. Het was wel aardig, maar niet spectaculair. Nog een tip: smeren met deet. Door al het water zitten er muggen.

title: fijn om te zien
text: Een krokodil aaien kan je niet elke dag, als je de kans krijgt, moet je het dan ook doen. Een bezoek aan deze poel is bij vele excursies inbegrepen. Ps: doe je excursies met een plaatselijke gids: er zijn er voldoende te vinden op internet die de nodige vergunningen hebben; Zo steun je de plaatselijke bevolking en is je bezoek vele persoonlijker als met een grote Tui of Corendon-bus

title: Krokodillen aanraken
text: Een aanrader als je in Gambia bent. Je krijgt de kans om een krokodil aan te raken. Een ervaring die je niet zo snel zal hebben in Europa

title: Great place to get up close to crocodiles
text: it is amazing to get up close and touch the crocodiles. The entrance fee could be a bit higher so that the guides can get their salary and the crocodiles their fish. You then know what you pay for and there is no need to harass visitors about donations and tips.

title: Great place to visit
text:
We were very interested to see and touch the crocodiles at Katchikally crocodile pool and hear about the history and beliefs of the local people. 
Touching a crocodile has to be a bucket list things to do & we were not disappointed. our guide explained how the crocs are cared for and fed and it was a very interesting trip.

title: Crocodile Pool
text: Leuke uitstap. Het museum was minder interessant, maar de Crocodile Pool was zeker de moeite! Heel leuk om ze van zo kortbij te kunnen zien en zelfs aanraken!

title: Make friends with the crocks
text: Waw! It was a very exciting experience visiting this very historic place in my own home town. The crocks are said to be sacred and believed to have healing powers.Good place to mingle and touch the crocks. The staff are very friendly and gives good info about the place.

title: Perfect for cocktails at sunset

title: Worth a look
text: Museum rooms are interesting, plenty of crocs to See, you can get up close and personal if you wish!!

title: Spannend
text: Graag eens een krokodil geaaid? Zorg wel dat er een gids van het park bij is! Aan de uitgang van het park zit ook een schilder die prachtige Afrikaanse schilderijen maakt.

title: Worth a visit
text: We visited this as a family, the museum is really interesting but small; it gives an insight to the history of the country including war and politics. The croc pool is okay, not sure how much I believe about them not chasing us cos they only eat fish.

title: Weer een leuk uitstapje met Lamin onze taxi chauffeur
text:
We hebben in januari 2018 Bakau Gambia bezocht. Onze taxi chauffeur en gids heeft ons ook naar de Crocodile Pool gebracht. Het was weer een leuk uitstapje met name de rit van het hotel naar de pool was een ware believing.
Als je een goede en betrouwbare  taxi chauffeur zoekt dan is Lamin een goede keus. Met zijn toestemming mocht ik zijn telefoonnummer vermelden. Je kunt hem bereiken met Whats App 002209822596. Hij rijdt rustig en is goed bekend met de omgeving. hij kent veel mensen en vraagt een eerlijke prijs. Een echte aanrader dus.

title: Mooie mythe
text:
Het verhaal achter de krokodillenvijver is een prachtige mythe. Het is o ongelooflijk om zoveel krokodillen.bij elkaar te zien
De belevenis staat of valt wel met de gids die je hebt, denk ik. Wij hadden een hele leuke, Moses, die veel plezier had in zijn werk. Ik vond het ook heel leuk om de krokodil vis te geven. Geen must-see maar toch zeker wel de moeite waard.

title: Up close and personal to crocodiles
text:
Crocodile pool - it's not everyday that you can get to stroke a crocodile but here you can.entrance fee is very cheap and as you walk through the museum you get a sense of history with all the artifacts and pictures on show,you then meander through the gardens hearing and seeing different birds until you come to the croc pool.a guide will go with you explaining about the origins of the pool(used for fertility rites) and take you to stroke crocodiles and will gladly take photos for you.
Excellent way to spend a couple of hours

title: Leuk!
text: Wij zijn er op de fiets naartoe gegaan vanuit Kotu. Mijn kinderen vonden het spannend om een keer te zien. Je loopt zo tussen de krokodillen door en met een goede gids erbij is het museum ook leuk om te zien. Je hoort dan de verhalen erachter.

title: Mixed Feelings!!
text:
My wife and I visited this crocodile pool while staying at the Senegambia Beach Hotel.
I have mixed feelings.
Although it was a great place to visit,
I could not help but feel that some of the animals were sedated.
It just do not seem right a load of people being able to go and touch a crocodile,
but again, having said this it was also a fantastic experience to do such a thing.
They do ask for a donation, although this is optional.
I would like to think that at least half of the donation is put towards the crocs food.
The surrounding area is a bit of an eye-opener, but do give you the chance to see close hand how the not so fortunate locals actually live.
It is worth going for the experience and close up site of these amazing creatures up close, just remain a bit open-minded by the experience.
Tip
If you are staying in or near the Senegambia Beach Hotel, get 'Del-Boy' to organise the tour for you. Well organised and worth the money. He is always down on the beach.

title: Leuk om te doen met lokale taxi
text: Wij zijn hier met Bamba mee naar toe gegaan. Als je met een lokale taxi gaat, lopen zij ook mee en kunnen ze je veel vertellen over het park. Bamba heeft ook Facebook, bamba taxi gambia

title: Great!
text: Definitely worth a visit amazing to sit by the mangrove whilst seeing the sea in the distance. Lovely drinks and food.

title: Mooie ervaring
text: Onze guide Bob heeft ons hier naartoe gebracht. Eerst zijn we door de compounds gelopen om een idee te krijgen van de community en hoe de bevolking hier leeft. Dit is zeker een aanraden om een de visit aan het crocodile pool nog mooier te maken. De krokodillen leven erg vredig, worden dagelijks gevoerd en zijn bijna allemaal tam.

title: Crocodiles up close
text: Katchikally Crocodile is easy to find, once in Bakau you only have to ask and you will be given directions, there is no need to join a your group. Don‚Äôt get fooled into signing a donation book near the entrance. Pay the entrance fee at the gate and walk around the pool / lake amongst the crocodiles, the crocs are well fed and take no notice of the tourists walking and standing next to them.

title: Leuk
text: Leuk om in een ochtend te doen .kan je leuk met krokodillen op de foto. Wij zijn er vanuit cape point zelf naartoe gelopen. kan makkelijk kijk wel eerst even op de Google Maps waar je moet zijn.

title: Something to do in Gambia
text:
Difficult to rate:

Before getting to the crocodile pool, there is a museum - 5 little huts: very interesting and informative. 
The crocodile pool is ok, lot of crocodile and there's a keeper that talks about the place. You can get up close to the crocodiles. You are allowed to touch the crocodile. Not sure if that is normal. The keeper said they feed them the night before so they are not hungry when tourist are around. 

The keeper will ask you to donate money to feed the crocodile. I wish I said No because you pay an entrance fee. I gave equivalent of less than $1 so that. 

The most uncomfortable part of this visit was the children at the entrance aggressively begging for money with directions/encouragement from their mothers.

title: Of two minds this is animal exploitation...
text: Conveniently placed for a quick trip from the hotel area and it is not a big attraction. Being an anti-city zoo, anti-circus type family this is NOT wild reptiles in a natural environment what ever the low price. And getting young children to bonk a maybe unhappy creature on the head is not setting a good example for future conduct with Africa wildlife.  Anyway they enjoyed the experience, pool men could be better informed and interactive in the job role.  Information centre was useful.

title: Difficult to rate
text:
Our todler had the best time at the crocodile pool. He really like petting the crocodiles. Kept talking about it all week.
But... this is not natural and in hindsight we should have never participated in this type of animal abuse. 
The adjacent museum is quite informative and we found it a pleasant surprise at this crocodile site.

title: One of the highlights of our trip
text: Crocodiles galore and you're even able to touch one if you dare! Fabulous to see so many together and all for 100 dalasi (less than ¬£2), over a hundred in and around the pool.

title: Well worth a visit...
text: We visited at new year 2018.  Had been here 31 years ago!  It is a small area...the crocks are cute and the little history museum is an interesting and useful addition.  You can (should) walk to it from the Cape Point hotels.

title: klein maar leuk
text: Voor 100 dhalasi is het leuke attractie. Tentoonstelling vooraf stelt niet veel voor. Wel heel veel krokodillen in kleine pool.

title: Feeding the crocs
text: This is a place to visit. The crocs are lovely warm creatures and there is always a keeper there. I actually fed them and stroked one. It's a must for animal lovers.

title: krokodil aaien...
text: Eerst kom je door de geschiedenis van Gambia(museum) daarna ga je naar een krokodillen pool. Ik waarschuw je gister goed wat ze zeggen want het blijven dieren die in de natuur leven!! Maar je krijgt de kans om een krokodil aan te raken/aaien. Erg leuk en toch ook een klein beetje spannend!

title: Scary
text:
Having grown up in Malawi and Zimbabwe found it quite scary watching my children touching a crocodile. 

Excellent activity for a family.

title: To touch a crocodile
text: You want to get as close as you have ever been to a crocodile. This is ideal. Not sure about the health and safety side of things but worth a vist. Don't expect too much it is fairly basic.

title: Aggressive guides
text: When we refused to talk to and shake hands with some annoying "guides" there, we were called racists. It is interesting to have a possibility to get in contact with crocodiles, I recommend this place for this opportunity, but beware of the "guides" at the pool

title: Good value experience
text:
Entrance was only 100 dalasi so good value. There's a museum on site, but I personally just wanted to touch a crocodile! Wasn't disappointed, there's looots of them in a small pool, lying around everywhere, calm and lazy just lounging. 
Nice place to spend part of your day - won't take more than an hour of your time!

title: An interesting excursion, but don't expect too much!
text:
Katchikally is one of those 'must see it' excursions that are thrust upon every visitor to the Gambia and, to be fair, it is an interesting way to spend an hour or two. Just don't expect a major tourist attraction - and we didn't find any toilets!
Quite simply, this is a rather muddy pool surrounded by trees and occupied by an assortment of tame crocodiles that do very little. It is apparently used for fertility rituals and is owned by one of the wealthiest families in Gambia
Yes, you can touch the crocodiles if you feel brave. You will be surrounded by other visitors most of the time and the 'keepers' will try (insistently) to sell you handmade crocodile teeth necklaces and other overpriced craft items.
I was slightly perturbed by the keeper's insistence that we should give him a 'donation' to pay for the crocodile's fish, especially as we had just paid to get in. Was this official or just another Bumster trick? I suspect the latter!
The best bit for me was the small museum at the venue's entrance. There are some interesting examples of local drums and musical instruments with some ceremonial costumes. I was particularly fascinated by the display of old photographs. For me, this was worth the entrance fee on its own.
In short, Katchikally is a tourist trap, but a relatively gentle one. The crocodile custodians are generally pleasant and you will almost certainly enjoy your visit.

title: Nothing spectacular
text: Ok but wouldn't travel a distance to visit. Journey through back streets seeing how locals live was more interesting.

title: Als je toch in de buurt bent ...
text:
Een plas met krokodillen en een museum van locale voudo. That's it.
De meeste toeristen gazn hier naartoe begeleid door een taxichauffeur die ook als gids speelt.

title: Great adventure
text: Amazing time, great guide to help us through the crocodile pools, keep an eye out as there is wildlife everywhere.

text: We were they only ones there ( apart from the guides) was very quiet and calm...there are literally 100 plus crocodiles, by your feet, no bands round their mouths, no obvious protection.  I thought it would be naff, thoroughly enjoyed it!!

title: Snappy Happy Crocs
text: Quite a small park where you will walk around a pool populated by crocodiles.Dens align the sides of the pool with baby crocs and mothers.They are well fed and looked after.

title: Crocs everywhere!
text: A gentle tour round the small museum, then on to see and touch the crocs. Was it scary - yes! However, we felt very safe with our guide and the Croc Pool staff.

title: Moet je doen als je in de buurt bent!
text:
Vanaf het hotel in Cape Point  zonder gids op eigen gelegenheid er naartoe gewandeld. Google Maps wijst de route perfect. Het is een belevenis op zich. 
Entree is 100 dalasi pp. Via 5 rond davels die dienst doen als museum met veel informatie mbt de geschiedenis van het land. Langs een zandpad kom je voorbij de oude boom waar vroeger besnijdenissen werden uit gevoerd. Net voor de pool wordt je opgevangen door een gids, hij vertelt het over het gebruik en betekenis van de heilige plaats. Hij heeft een paar fotos gemaakt toen wij de krokodillen aaide, leuk om te doen!
Aan het eind hebben wij de gids 100 dalasi gegeven voor de uitleg.

title: A place to visit
text:
A  nice walk through a forest/jungle with lots to see, and then there's t
lots of crocodiles in ponds and walking around. You actually not very far from them

title: Very cool
text: The people running it were easy going and friendly - we enjoyed our visit! I even picked up a crocs tail!

title: Tof om mee te maken
text:
We zijn hier heen gegaan met een lokale gids en lokale taxichauffeur. Er zit een grappig museum bij met allemaal uitleg en attributen van de bewoners van Gambia. Vervolgens loop je via een bos met een zeer oude boom naar een vijver waar allemaal krokodillen liggen. Je kan ze aanraken, voeden met vis en foto's en video maken.  

Heb niet het idee dat de dieren mishandeld worden.

title: Dundee
text:
Went through the museum at the beginning where your shown a bit of the history of the Gambian people going all the way back to their magical beliefs up to when the queen visited and also the recruiting of troops from Gambia in the Second World War 

The crocodile pool is pretty good they‚Äôll be couple out the water where they‚Äôll be a chance to have your photo taken with the crocs. They‚Äôll also explain about the spiritual beliefs of the pool. 

On the whole not a bad bit of money spent buy don‚Äôt get prepared to be blown away

title: A crocodile petting zoo with local heritage museum
text:
We‚Äôve been here early October before high Season (Oct 15th-Dec)

It‚Äôs a small place best visited out of season. The guides have time to show you around and tell something about the crocs.

If you take of one of the locals to take you there you can stay away from the tourist traffic days. I wouldn‚Äôt wanna be there when there‚Äôs a group of 20-30 tourist that just got there.

That said, it‚Äôs good fun and a good thrill. Even though they‚Äôre well fed with fish, it‚Äôs still an exciting event to be able to touch them and feel the skin of these prehistoric survivors.

Entrance fee is about 100 dalasi.

This includes the museum with some of the festive and traditional clothing, music instruments and the juju (voodoo) department.

title: Snappy!
text: We had a great time here. The museum first of all was insightful, learning about local tribes and their tools of trade. Then through to see the crocs. There were a lot of crocs so everyone could take turns in stroking them. The keepers would tell you which ones to stay away from and which ones to touch. They were on the ball and made sure everyone was safe. Even my children got to touch them. Great place to visit.

title: Crocodile pool in a very poor neighborhood.
text: We visited the crocodile with a local guide. He did not know the location exactly so we stranded a few hundred meters from the entrance. The road are terrible and if you have to walk you realize you walking along open sewer. First thing to visit is the museum that gives a good impression of the area in the old days. When you walk along you will find the crocodiles that have been fed already so you are able to touch them. Around the pool it is relative clean but the garbage has been thrown into the behind the trees it looks like a garbage disposal area. Still touching the crocodiles is a special experience.

title: Excursies Met lokale gids Yaya Mannah
text: Ervaring zoveel krokodillen en het lijkt ongevaarlijk om ze aan te raken. Ik heb het voorzichtig toch gedaan.

title: Been able to touch the crocsüôÑüôÑüôÑ
text: Went to see crocs, touched a live croc and it didnt bite me. Believe me cro s were evefywhere liten to the guides an obey what they tell you.

title: A unique experience - MUST visit place
text:
This was my second time to Gambia and I could not miss to visit this place one more time.  Last time it was summer so the pool was not full of water but this time it was raining and the experience was simply amazing.  The pool was full of water so could not see the Crocs lying on the side.
You enter the park by paying a nominal fee and if lucky find crocodiles walking along with you on the side or may be just lying next to the walking path.  They are harmless until she is a female.  Female is more into defense to protect her eggs.  You reach near the pool and find so many of them just lying over there, may be waiting for you to sit besides them and have your pictures taken.  Believe me, it is an amazing experience irrespective you like animals or not.  These Crocs are never fed meat and they eat almost 3,000 Kg of fish daily (that's what rangers told, not sure how much true it is).  Please make sure that the rangers are around and guide you which Croc to be with while taking the pictures.  Stay away from the female Crocs.  If the water level is a bit low in the pool then you can go close by and see many Crocs walking towards you from the water or the side.  There is nothing to worry about but you must need to take precautions while with animals.  There is a small shop that sells crocodile tooth and they are not expensive, may be around 150 - 200 dalasis.  They also ask for the donation and have maintained a register of donors.
They have a nicely maintained museum in the front that depicts many ancient and authentic articles including weapons, cooking vessels, musical instruments etc.  There is also a history of Gambia associated with it if you are interested into it.
It is a belief of the locals that a lady who is not able to conceive a baby can visit this place and take a dip in the pool to be an expectant mom in the future.

title: Impactante
text: Interesante ver y tocar a estos animales en una visita tambi√©n cultural, donde puedes visitar su museo y ver parte de la historia de este pa√≠s.

title: Nice and creepy
text:
A trip to Bakau is more than visiting a crocodile pool. You also see how poor this neighbourhood is. Pretty shocking. Children are happy if you give them something to eat or something small like a ball. 
Bakau pool is completely filled with crocs. You have to see it to believe it. You can touch them ( I' m not a fan). I' ve filmed it for my pupils, they found me an awesome teacher :-)
